item.title: How to Uninstall Ubuntu from Windows
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded:
So you have a dual booted computer. Maybe you did it out of curiosity, boredom, or challenge. Maybe you have Ubuntu and Windows, Arch and OSX, or all of them. However, dual-booting isn't for everyone. Some of us have to work and study on our computers, which can call for the use of operating system exclusive software. Dual-booting takes up a lot of hard disk space, and it takes time to change OS (Especially into Windows). Wine and Virtual Machines can help cross OS boundaries where dual-booting fails. I prefer Virtual Machines; I can boot an OS quickly, run the software, and save my progress. The dual-boot method requires me to boot into the OS, run the software, and wait for it to finish. Then, I have to boot back into my primary operating system. Additionally, I have to lug the operating system on my hard drive. Reinstalling a Linux platform happens quite often. It is easy to "brick" Linux, especially distros such as Arch Linux. Other reasons for reinstalling may include renewed speed, partition resizing, style customization redoes, and a fresh start. Deleting a Operating System from Windows is simple; expect it to take no more than 5 minutes.
  • This tutorial deletes an 200GB Ubuntu 12.04 partition with a 20GB swap using Windows 8 64 bit. The deletion process will be essentially the same if you have Windows Vista or above, and deleting any Linux distro.
  • Right click "Computer" and click "Manage"
  • Go to "Storage" then "Disk management"
  • At this point, make sure you are certain which partition is the operating system you want to delete. If you delete your recovery partition or a different OS, you're gonna have a bad time. If necessary, use partition managing software such as GParted to make sure.
  • We will delete two partitions: The actual operating system and the swap partition.
  • Right click the partition you want to delete and confirm the deletion. The picture above depicts the confirmation. It will take a few seconds, and will result in unallocated space.
  • Right click the swap partition and delete it as well. Again, make sure it's the Operating System's swap. It will result in unallocated space.
  • Say your final parting goodbye to the operating system.
How easy was that? I freed myself from a 200GB Ubuntu partition, and I plan on installing a fresh, new OS: Debian. And with my increased knowledge in Linux, I won't bloat it or have trouble customizing.

item.title: Ultimate Animated GIF Making Guide
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded:
Animated GIFs are rising in popularity everyday. They are frequently found on popular sites that use images; such as Tumblr, 4chan, and forums throughout the Internet. An animated GIF is essentially a video clip in the form of an image. This allows amazing portability; an image can be freely uploaded on many Internet communities, but videos usually don't support embed. We see GIFs everywhere now. But where do they come from? How can we make them? There are several ways to create GIFs. They vary greatly in method and difficulty. Click the method title for more information.

GIF Viewing Application: GIF Viewer 4

Before making GIFs, a proper GIF viewing application is recommended. GIFs open in your browser on default, and that can be annoying when you're trying to simply open an image, especially on slow hardware. GIF Viewer 4 is the solution to that problem.

Method 1 : Directly From Your Screen

- Difficulty : Very Easy - Customizability : Low - Quality : High http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lhTKpzS6Dqo GifCam allows you to screen capture an animated GIF directly form your screen. This is my personal favorite; simply ready a frame and start making GIFs. It also supports a little bit of customization. The video above is a quick demonstration of gifcam.

Method 2 : From Individual Images

- Difficulty : Easy - Customizability : High - Quality : Normal CaptureIt Plus is a screenshot utility software, but also comes with a GIF creator. It allows you to select images to turn into a GIF. You can customize the framerate, image size, and many other things.

Method 3 : From Video

- Difficulty : High - Customizablity : Very High - Quality : Fully Customizable It is possible to create GIFs from Video. It uses the GNU Image Manipulation Program (GIMP), and requires the Graphics Animation Package (GAP). This requires more work, but allows customization of nearly every aspect the GIF. You can pick any part of the video, edit individual frames, edit framerate, edit size, etc. If you've seen a well made GIF that made you think "who had the time to make this"? Chances are it was created using this method. Here's Chakeda's video tutorial on this method: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3alKZi3nfHM

Method 4 : Use an online service

- Difficulty : Easy - Customizability : Low - Quality : Low There are many online services that can create GIFs for you. Some are online converters, some generate from individual images. Google is your best friend in the search to find the best one for you. http://makeagif.com/ - This website has many options to create a gif, ranging from individual images to YouTube Video conversion. However, they will slap a watermark on the image. Therefor, using the first 3 methods is preferable for a quality GIF. http://www.zamzar.com/ - Zamzar supports many file conversions. It can make an entire video file into an animated GIF. However, there are no options to customize, so Method 3 is preferable.

Conclusion

Now you know every single way to create an Animated GIF. GIFs are being used more frequently than ever with the advent of Internet communities and social media. Found another method? Share it with us at our Facebook Page.

item.title: How to Change Your IP Address in Windows 8
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded:
Phew, October was a rough month. Sometimes you just want to change your identity and start anew, forgetting all of the past history. Unfortunately in life, that isn't an easy process. However, on the Internet, it is fairly easy. Simply change your IP and you are a new person. There are two types of IP addressing: Static and Dynamic. Static IP's never change, and therefore are susceptible to IP bans from websites and IP specific settings. Proxies can be used to temporarily hide you IP, but proxies have several disadvantages. Many people use proxies to change and hide their internet identities. However, many websites can identify proxies easily, and block you from doing anything on their site -- even deny you access. Also, proxies are painfully slow. The solution to this is dynamic IP address assignment. Whenever you reset your router, you get a new IP address. You can start anew whenever you feel like it! With this, you won't be afraid of IP bans or IP specific cookies: you are a new man everytime. It's like going in the Pay n' Spray of GTA4.

How to Enable Dynamic IP Address Assignment in Windows 8

- Right click your network bars on your bottom right, and Open Network and Sharing Center. - It should look like the first image. - Click your current Wi-Fi connection. - Wi-Fi Status will open. Click Properties. - Wi-Fi Properties will open. Select IPv4. Click Properties. - IPv4 Properties will open. Enable Obtain an IP address automatically. - Enable Obtain and IP address automatically for IPv6 as well, using the same process. - Your IP address will now change if you reset your router.

Testing DHCP: Changing your IP

- google "whats my ip". - Write down your current IP. - Unplug your router and wait about 30 seconds. - Plug your router back in. - When your Internet is back up, google "whats my ip" again. - You should have a new IP address!

Video:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wzhG4HYvvlo

item.title: iMacro : Automate Repetitive Web Tasks
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded:
Have you ever found yourself repeating the same thing over and over on the Internet? Have you ever noticed you're doing something on a website that a simple robot could do? Have you ever wanted to automate the Internet? iMacro is a extremely powerful Firefox add-on that can automate web tasks for you. As you can see in the picture above, you can fill out an entire web form just with a click of a button. It can autofill massive forms spanning multiple pages; and information is stored in editable plain text. It also supports a master password system where the user need only to remember one password, and iMacro knows the rest, encrypted in 256-bit AES. However, iMacro can do so much more than automatically fill out applications. It can effectively be used as a web scraper and data extractor, automating tasks such as e-mail scraping or web store price checking. This is fully customizable due to iMacro's own scripting language, which can be shared to other iMacro users. This is the iMacro (.iim) script of the gif seen above. As you can see, it is not complicated code at all. Additionally, these scripts are compliant with JavaScript, allowing supreme extensibility. This allows conditional statements, loops, and the entire JavaScript library at your power. Combined with iMacros, you can potentially program the Internet. As you can see, if you have knowledge of JavaScript and iMacro, you can automate anything you can do with Firefox. However, extensive knowledge of both is not required to do simple, repetitive tasks.

Example: Record and Share a Form Fill

iMacro allows you to record a session. You don't have to code anything; simply start recording, and do what you want iMacro to do. It's best to see this capability through an example. In this gif, I record a form fillout and save it: That was extremely simple. Now iMacro saves this as an .iim file. You can send this to anyone, and they can play it as long as they have iMacro as well. Instead of telling people how to use a form, send them a iMacro to do it form them. Makes it easy for both parties. Simply double-click the saved macro to play it again:

Conclusion

The most common use of iMacros is to automate form filling. However, iMacros can do anything Firefox can do. Whether it would be data extraction, e-mail scraping, downloading/uploading files, web testing, stress testing, be a password manager, spammer, poll stuffer, offer completer; it can potentially do it. It can be combined with other extensions such as Greasemonkey and Firebug. Contact us on facebook if you need iMacro help. iMacro Links - Download iMacro from Mozilla - For those with Chrome - Official Website - iMacro Programming Documentation - How to make awesome animated gifs :)

item.title: ZArchiver : Android File Archiver
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded: File archiving is a necessary function for all computers. Compression facilitates the uploading/downloading of files by reducing the size. Security can be implemented as well; most compression file types support password protection. As evidenced by the short 7zip compression research, some archive formats are better than others. Android natively supports simple zip archiving. However, it doesn't have password protection or superior 7zip compression. It is more likely for your smartphone to be stolen than your computer. It can slip out of your pocket, get robbed of, or pickpocketed. If the thief sees your phone, he will most likely bypass your common pattern lock (A z-pattern? Too easy) and have access to all of your files. If you have ES File Explorer, you made this process so much easier for him. This is why password protecting files is important for Android. ZArchiver supports many compression types, password protection, decompression (from zip to iso) and many other features. Security is important; with the advent of smartphones, the most vulnerable gadget, identity thievery is common. Password protecting files is one of the most easiest and important ways to protect your files. Get ZArchiver at the Play Store.

item.title: Gif Viewing Application : Gif Viewer

item.content:encoded: So you have been introduced into the world of creating GIFs from our several methods. You've saved GIFs and created GIFs. But when you open the image, it opens it in Firefox. You can't browse through them without opening multiple tabs; you have to push your computer pretty hard to browse your GIFs. GIF Viewer 4 is a lightweight application that can view GIFs. You get a quick preview of an GIF on your PC, without having to open your browser. You can also browse all other images using your arrow keys, allowing for easy navigation of all your images. It's recommended you set the default application to open GIFs with GIF viewer. As seen on the image above, GIF Viewer 4 has everything you need to watch your GIFs. There isn't much else I can explain for GIF Viewer 4: other than that it's the best application to view your GIFs with. Download GIF Viewer 4 from their official website.

item.title: How to run Windows 8.1 in Virtualbox
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded:
In October, we went over how to run Windows XP in VirtualBox. Windows XP is a very simple operating system, so setting it up in VirtualBox is fairly easy. However, Windows 8.1 is a complex, heavyweight operating system. We will need slightly more effort to configure a virtual environment for it. Virtualizing Windows 8.1 is primarily used for previewing the OS. People want to make sure they're getting the bang for the buck. Granted, I believe Windows 8.1 is better than its predecessor. They have a start button, and metro is slightly more cleaned up. Other than that, they're not that different. Other than previewing, a Windows 8.1 virtual machine can allow users to run modern Windows applications. A Linux user or a Mac user will find the need to run Windows applications quite often. Windows XP simply won't cut it; most applications cannot run in Windows XP, due to either the lack of resources or deprecation. Expect this to take about 15 minutes. If you've dual-booted or used VirtualBox before, you will be familiar with BIOS or configuring the VM. Note: The Host OS (Actual computer I use) is Windows 8.

Requirements

- Oracle Virtualbox - Download it at Oracle's official website. - Windows 8.1 .iso - Find it online. You can find a copy on Piratebay. Make sure you use a Open Source P2P Client: Deluge. - For this tutorial, use a 32 Bit, x86 architecture Windows 8.1 iso. 64 bit versions will require huge sizes of RAM and CPU, which is bad for virtualization.

Step 1: Enable Virtualization Technology in BIOS

- We will enter our Computers BIOS. - To do this, hit F12 immediately upon starting your computer. - Every computer has a different BIOS. Entering BIOS may have a different key than F12. Use google to find out how if you're stuck. - Simply use your arrow keys to navigate to the option Enable Virtualization Technology. - Make sure it is enabled. - Save changes and boot to your Desktop. - Without this step, VirtualBox will not support the graphic requirements for Windows 8.1 virtualization, and the following error will occur. 
ERROR: VT-x/AMD-V hardware acceleration is not available on your system. Certain guests (e.g. OS/2 and QNX) require this feature and will fail to boot without it.

Step 2: Configuring Windows 8.1 for VirtualBox.

- Launch VirtualBox. - Create a New VM with a Windows 8.1 operating system. - Use all the default configuration settings. - Refer to Step 2 of the VirtualBox Windows XP tutorial if you are inexperienced with virtual machines. - Once the Virtual Machine is configured, start it.

Step 3: Installing Windows 8.1

- If all goes well, Windows 8 will start and ask which language you'd like to install. - After that, select Custom: Install Windows only (advanced). This is because we are installing windows on our virtual hard drive, not upgrading from 8 to 8.1. - Follow the rest of the personalization prompts. Expect to give Windows all of your information for their advertising purposes. - It will install windows upon completion. Expect this to take a while. - Upon completion, you get the rainbow colors of congratulation. Images and Text can make for a confusing tutorial to most readers. Here is a video, so you can know that this method works and that it won't blow up your computer. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6axqvNK1S54

item.title: Netbeans : Best PHP Programming IDE
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded: A few weeks ago we looked at Notepad++. A very lightweight and simple text editor, it has the bare minimum to get things done in a project. Syntax coloring, search and replace, and function lists are a necessity; and Notepad++ satisfies it. However, its only good for quick patching and small functions. When we're confronted by projects and applications, we need an Integrated Development Environment (IDE); a software application that builds comprehensive facilities to developers. NetBeans IDE is one of the most popular IDE's, because of it's myriad of features. And of course, it is free open source software. Here is a list of some of NetBean's features. - Cross Platform (Windows, Linux, OSX) - Auto-complete - "getter and setter" generation - "instant rename" - parameter tooltips - built-in web server - array referencing/dereferencing - fluent instantiation (anonymous object variables) - semantic code highlighting - marking of occurences and exit points - dynamically integrated with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript - PHP debugging using Xdebug - Search and replace throughout the project I don't even know what half of these mean. But we can infer that there is abundant functionality to program, and more to learn from the IDE. All I know is that in my time using NetBeans, I have not been disappointed. You have EVERYTHING you need to program PHP. It facilitates reading code, such as searching a function and all of its occurrences will be shown. Then I can fix it up a file error using Notepad++ and send it up to my FTP. There are many different PHP IDE's out there, varying in functionality. However, most are proprietary. According to this wikipedia article, there are only 6 other free PHP IDE's. They lack functionality in comparison to NetBeans, as you can see from the chart. In the free open source market, PHPEclipse may be the only IDE that can begin to compare with NetBeans. Combine this with Firebug and Windows Internet Information Systems, and you have a powerful web deveopment environment. Check out more of NetBeans IDE's features at their official website.

item.title: Create Animated GIFs with CaptureIt Plus
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded: Back in September, we reviewed Greenshot, a powerful screen capture tool. It is definitely one of the best free screen capture tools, due to its user-friendliness and extensibility. However, something that it lacks is the ability to generate GIFs. CaptureIt Plus is another free open source screen capture utility for Windows. It can do most of what Greenshot can do, but it has a GIF generator. I use Greenshot for Screenshots, and CaptureIt for creating animated GIFs out of individual images. Way back in July, we went over how to create animated GIFs with GIMP. However, this method is strictly for creating GIFs from video formats such as mp4 and avi. CaptureIt's GIF generator allows you to select images and create a GIF from them; a slideshow as an image, if you will. You can select the resolution and what speed the pictures change. The GIF seen above shows you exactly how to create the GIF. I used four 768 x 1366 PNGs. I selected a 3 second interval, and kept the resolution default. The resolution is shot, because I went from PNG to GIF. However, I really like this, as I only have to post ONE IMAGE to make a tutorial. This would have greatly simplified my Virtual Machine Tutorial. For those who prefer a textual tutorial, here's how to create an animated GIF using CaptureIt's GIF generator Tool. You can follow the GIF above and these steps. - Download CaptureIt Plus from CodePlex. - Install and Run. - In your bottom right Icons, right click CaptureIt Plus - Running. - Mouse over Tools, and click GIF generator. - The GIF generator tool will popup. - Browse to the images you want to make into a GIF. - ctrl-click the images you want in order. - Click finish when finished. - Select the interval between each image for the GIF. - Finish! Creating GIFs from images is alot more simple than creating GIFs from video. The image way is better for creating tutorials and mini slideshows, but making smooth, presentable GIFs are best made with Video. However, the easiest and fastest way to create a GIF is using the screen capture tool Gifcam: It creates a window that can record a gif directly from your screen. As an end note, CaptureIt Plus can be used as an Alternative for Greenshot.

item.title: Wireshark : Open Source Packet Sniffer
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded:
Electronic data is sent in small pieces called packets. When we access a website, many packets are sent to and from our computer and the website server. Wireshark finds these packets, and displays them to you with microscopic detail in a human readable format. Now I'm not going into detail, as networking is remarkably complex. However, Wireshark is very user-friendly, and a novice can easily pick it up and use it to their advantage with a little practice. Many Industries and Universities use Wireshark for penetration testing, networking, and information technology.(George Mason University's Computer Science course has a pdf tutorial on Wireshark). Casual users can use it creatively: such as finding nice little treasures in the packets. With Wireshark, we can uncover things that are not displayed on our side. A simple example is shown below. Here, I selected to monitor my Wi-fi's traffic and filtered Wireshark to only show traffic from my website. Both downloaded and uploaded data are shown. It friendlily shows me that it http (directly) downloaded a text/css file from the webserver, and it gave me the 200 OK (request succeeded). Wireshark even goes as far as displaying the text/css that was sniffed. Handy! To filter traffic from a specific website, the syntax is: 
ip.src==<Website IP Address>
To find a website's IP address, simply use an online service. This is the very first step of using wireshark. Just by messing around, you can eventually get acclimated to reading traffic and start sniffing treasures better than some text/css file. This can potentially be used to grab media from sites; it's uses are only limited by your imagination, as I always say. Download Wireshark from their official site, read their documentation, and start to Go Deep.

item.title: 7zip : Strongest Compression Type
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded:
We've all dealt with compressed files before. Almost everything we download is a .zip file. This is because zip files are small and faster to download than raw bulky source. Also zip files automatically provide an http download link when directed to in a web browser. Like this. 7zip is an open source compression application that can make .7z files which are smaller than .zip. The compression results are dependent on the data, but can range from 30-70% more compression than zip (7zip official website). The application can also read and write other compression formats. Windows 8 already has the ability to create and read compressed files, so 7zip isn't as much as a necessity as it was in Windows 7. I remember back in the XP days I had no idea how to deal with compressed files. I downloaded winrar from an obviously unsafe site after hours of trying to open the archive. Wish I knew of open source 7zip before I destroyed that computer. However, both versions of Windows can't read and write 7z files; which are pretty much zip's on steroids. Below is a comparison of zip/7z compression for a 43.1MB archive. The archive is 1226 files and 50 folders mainly consisting of images. We see here the 7zip compressed 1.7MB more. 
ZIP: 37.2/43.1 = 0.8631 | 86.31% compression
7Z: 35.5/43.1 = 0.8237 | 82.37% compression
In conclusion, 7zip's claim that their compression is 30-70% better than ZIP may be exaggerated. We see 3.94% more compression in 7zip to zip. As stated, their compression relies heavily on the archive's data types. I would assume images aren't their strongest suit. I would need alot more testing for different file types for a definite conclusion. Feel free to share your own calculations and tests. I'd also like to add that the 7zip compression took a shorter time to complete: approximately 7 seconds. The Windows 8 ZIP compression took about 10 seconds. But I digress. 7zip allows you to read ad write .7z archives, a common, popular, and powerful archive format. Download 7zip from their official website.
