item.title: BleachBit : Free Diskspace and Protect Privacy
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded: We all have bits of tiny information left on our computer from being on the Internet: our Internet History isn't the only keeper of the past. The image above says it all. That was the result of running BleachBit for the first time. I was astonished by the amount of unnecessary, unknown data I have accumulated. I mean "yooohtube"? "red*ube"? "miniclip"? Some of these sites I have never even heard of before. Apparently these websites have been storing information on our computers, unbeknownst to us. This is unacceptable: BleachBit will completely wipe this unnecessary data. Free and Open Source, BleachBit allows you to clear data from Flash, Firefox, IE, Windows Explorer, FileZilla, Skype, OpenOffice, and many other applications; even your system temp files. Your application will still be functional: you'll keep your bookmarks and settings, but these unnecessary caches and cookies from websites will be wiped. Things like "recently used" and temp files can be used to monitor what you did on your shared computer. BleachBit is the solution. Also, I cleaned 235.4 MB of hard disk space. But most importantly, these websites you saw above have stored information in our computers, without our permission. Let's wipe it all up, stay private, and start fresh. As you can see here, you have freedom of what to delete and what not to delete. Cleaning your entire computer of junk will take a long time, and just cleaning your Firefox data will take a few seconds. Very easy to use; just point and click. Let's enjoy our freedom. Install BleachBit from SourceForge.

item.title: How to Run Windows XP in VirtualBox
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded:
Step By Step Tutorial:

  Remember the times when computers weren't competing to be "innovative"? When using the computer meant using the computer, instead of watching advertisements? (Looking at you Windows 8). Well we can return and use Windows XP using Oracle's VirtualBox. Instead of recovering nostalgia, running an virtual machine can be used in numerous ways. As the name states, a virtual machine is a fictive computer running in your computer. VirtualBox runs an operating system in a window; they simply emulate the functions of a real computer. Here are some uses of a VM. - You can run two computers on your computer. Maybe even three or four. Multiply your computing capability. - You can run different operating systems, to cross the boundary of platform-specific applications. - You can run server operating systems, and make backups on Virtual Servers. You can't lose a virtual server easily. - Trying new operating systems using VM's can be beneficial, in case you are accident prone. - Got a dangerous, volatile application? Run it in an VM, because you can easily make a new a virtual system. How easy is it to make a new virtual system, you ask? This tutorial will teach you how.

Step 1: Getting what we need

VirtualBox - First, let's download the VM application. - Download it from Oracle here. - Install it. Windows XP Operating System - Now what we need is the .iso file for the Windows XP operating system. - Where do you get it? Go on PirateBay and torrent a copy of a Windows XP iso. - I'm not responsible for anything, but it's not dangerous to torrent Windows XP: as long as you use an open-source P2P client, i.e. Deluge.

Step 2: Configuring the Virtual Machine

- Run VirtualBox. It should look like the picture above, but you don't have the VM "Test". - Hit "New", the blue star. - The first prompt ask you what operating system the VM will be. Type XP, and it will automatically make it XP for you. - You can blow through all other prompts with the defaults. It will be functional. - If you're familiar with hardware, you can configure it how you like. - The VM is configured and ready to be set up. - Select the new VM and hit start. - It will prompt you to select a start-up disk. Hit the folder icon to browse to the location of your .iso file. - Now we can proceed to installing XP.

Step 3: Installing Windows XP

- We're gonna go through a bunch of blue screens and we can't use the mouse. - Hit enter. Let's start the set-up process. - Hit Enter. We would like to make the virtual hard into C:. - Hit Enter. We would like it to be a NTFS partition, yes. - Give a couple minutes and it will set up. - When the set-up is done, it will reboot.

Running Windows XP

- Now we got all of the technical things done. - Upon reboot, Windows XP starts up. - The rest is setting up and personalizing Windows XP. - Set it up to your liking. - Eventually, It will ask for the Activation Key. - Google it, and you will find it. Piratebay has several keys as well. Well that was simple, wasn't it? If not, feedback is always appreciated. - If the VM has trouble booting, try making the CD/DVD the top priority in the boot order.

item.title: Firebug : Swiss Army Knife for Web Development
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded: Firebug is an open-source Firefox Add-on that facilitates the debugging, editing, and monitoring of a websites CSS, HTML, DOM, Javascript, and even Network Connections. The image above shows the editable CSS that I use frequently. Yes, this is a very similar tool to Firefox Web Tools, the built-in web development toolbox. They have approximately the same capabilities, but I believe Firebug is superior. Mostly because it looks better. Firebug isn't aimed solely towards web developers; it can be useful for people who want to know what's happening behind the scenes of a website. As seen above, Firebug can identify the network connections the website displays. This is great for web security. You can see where a website connects to, so use firebug on a suspicious website or an infected website: The answer may be right there. Also show us all the errors here. Apparently my header image is missing. You can inspect an HTML element with a right click. What CAN'T Firebug do? Lastly, firebug has a very powerful Javascript console. I'm talking very, very powerful. Here's a list of all the capabilities of the Javascript debugger/console from the Official Firebug Website. If I start listing them here, the power will be overwhelming. The download link is right there as well. The console can be used for web security and applications development. Get creative with it.

item.title: How to Dual-Boot Windows 8 and Ubuntu 12.04
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded:
So you got a new computer. It has Windows 8, as retailers mandate. A couple minutes after using your new computer you realize you don't like Windows 8. Most likely the reason is Metro: A tablet interface on a laptop. That's way too different -- most people prefer simplicity and usability for their computers. So you have three options: - Rage at Microsoft for pushing such a incomplete, incapable, ad-ridden OS and file a complaint, in which they will redirect you to Lashawnda, customer support extraordinaire. The resulting conversation drives you to madness, leading to the mutilation of your computer. Then you buy a Macbook. There's $2500 down the drain. - Pay $200 for windows 7 and spend 6 days trying to backup files and install, then file a complaint for a refund in which you will be prompted to buy the windows repair kit (only 69.99!). The endless metempsychosis of repair and installation results in $3000 wasted. - Dual boot Ubuntu alongside Windows 8. The best option? It should be obvious: install a new, simple, usable operating system; namely Ubuntu.

What Ubuntu 12.04 looks like

Ubuntu is the most popular Linux-based operating system. When people hear the word Linux, they think of command lines and no user interface. But Ubuntu, as you see above, is very pretty and user-friendly. Well what are you waiting for? Let's install this beautiful, user-friendly, customizable, lightweight, freedom respecting operating system right now.

Step 1: Create a bootable USB drive

 
Warning: This is a tutorial for Windows 8 and Ubuntu 12.04. Your computer is most likelt different from my computer: If things go off from the steps provided, use common sense or google.
- I have an HP Pavilion 17 TouchSmart. If you have an HP computer, the process should be almost exactly the same as this tutorial. - First, Download the official Ubuntu Distribution. - Navigate to the Desktop download page. - Check your system to see what flavour you need. Newer computers are x64, older are x32. - You will now download the ubuntu.iso file. - An .iso file is a file that has the contents of a CD in it. - Now that you have the essence of Ubuntu upon your hard drive, lets burn it onto a USB drive. - Prepare an empty USB drive. You will have to wipe everything on it in order to create a bootable USB. - Burn your ubuntu to your USB drive using pendrivelinux. - Download the application. - Launch the application, and find the ubuntu .iso file to burn to the stick. The process is simple, use your common sense. - You now have a bootable Ubuntu USB stick. Keep the USB in the computer for the following steps.

How the USB burn should look like, according to pendrivelinux:

Step 2: Boot Ubuntu

- NOTE: If you want to create your own partitions for Ubuntu, look up how to do it and do it now, as we are starting the installation process. This is only recommended for advanced users. You can arbitrarily size during Ubuntu installation. - Swipe from the right / move your mouse to the top right of your screen. - Go to settings. - click power. - Hold Shift and click restart. This will put you in a blue screen: special boot mode. This was an old trick utilized in Windows XP. - You should be at a blue screen now.

Blue screen looks like this.

- click Use a Device - click USB Drive (UEFI) - Now we will enter our computers boot system. Fortunately, Ubuntu is compliant with the new UEFI firmware interface, so this process is much easier than other Linux system installations. - (If it says The Selected Boot Device has Failed, just hit enter.) - You should be at a UEFI screen now, with options like OS Boot manager and Ubuntu. OS boot manager will take you to Windows 8.

UEFI screen looks like this, but with Ubuntu Boot Options.

- Use the arrow keys to navigate to Ubuntu (not safe mode), then hit enter. - Then you'll get to a purple screen, that looks similar to the UEFI screen. - Use arrow keys to navigate to Ubuntu again, and hit enter. (again, not safe mode or recovery) - Now you should see your beautiful Ubuntu Desktop.

Welcome to the Ubuntu!

Step 3: Installing Ubuntu

- We are currently running on the USB stick's Ubuntu file. - Now we have to make this OS a functional part of the hard drive. - The installer is easy though; just follow the directions. - Launch the installer on your desktop. - Select your language.

Almost there...

- Now you can delete your entire disk and install ubuntu, but this tutorial is about dual booting. We want the functionality of both Windows and Linux. - Click install Ubuntu alongside them, and it will prompt you to size your partitions for Ubuntu and Windows. - The one on the right is Ubuntu. I would recommend 20 gigabytes if you are testing it out. I have a 1TB hard drive, and I use Ubuntu often, so I threw 50 gigs on it. Keep in mind you can keep data in another partition: So I recommend 20 - 50 gigabytes to the indecisive. - Simply drag the line in the middle to size the partitions. - Continue through some non-technical things as it installs, such as Time zones and basic settings. - It will install eventually, and finish with no problems. - Ubuntu is now installed alongside Windows. Congratulations!

Step 4: Switching between Windows and Ubuntu

- Now that we have both operating systems functional, let's learn how to boot from Windows to Linux, and vice versa. - Let's go to Windows from here. First, shut down your computer. - If you restart instead of shut down from Ubuntu to Windows, some audio problems may occur, so shut down when you want to go from Ubuntu to Windows. - When you turn on your computer, Windows will boot. Let's go back to Ubuntu. - As described in step 2, boot from USB device in the Blue screen. - If the Selected Boot Device Failed, hit enter. - UEFI screen. Navigate with arrow keys to Ubuntu, hit enter. - Purple screen. Navigate with arrow keys to Ubuntu, hit enter. - And we're back at Ubuntu!

Step 5: Closing Statements

Ubuntu has everything you need, and is very user-friendly. The first time I encountered Linux was when I was a freshman in high school. It was very easy to use, and lots of fun to mess with. Our school had EdUbuntu installed on our Netbooks. I remember how we had a lot of fun customizing our laptops; it eventually became a competition to see who can make the most complicated desktop. We messed with the command line, which lead to programming; and my interest for computers started there with the encounter of Linux. Linux will teach you a new level of computing. From this simple tutorial, we brushed the concept of disk partitions, and how operating systems work. The command line will give you lots of cognitive exercise and problem solving skills; many who use Linux find it entertaining to use the command line. Don't like the command line, and simply want to get to work? Ubuntu is a perfectly functional OS melding usability and friendliness. The command line can be sued by the curious and the software center for the working type. If you need to uninstall Ubuntu, here's the guide. Stay tuned by liking our Facebook Page, and as always, feedback is appreciated.

item.title: Greenshot : The Best Screenshot Utility
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded: Many of you have done this before: Take a screenshot, then take ages editing it with paint. Greenshot makes that and other processes much faster. I got Greenshot yesterday, and I had way too much fun playing with it. It's a lightweight, free, open source, screenshot tool that can do pretty much anything you want a screenshot tool to do. Capabilities include but are not limited to: - Quickly create screenshots of a selected region, window or fullscreen; you can even capture complete (scrolling) web pages from Internet Explorer. - Easily annotate, highlight or obfuscate parts of the screenshot. - Export the screenshot in various ways: save to file, send to printer, copy to clipboard, attach to e-mail, send Office programs or upload to photo sites like Flickr or Picasa, and others. Software Developers, Technical Writers, Graphic Designers, Imageboard Addicts, and Bloggers all need to take screenshots. Greenshot makes that easier. Check out a couple things I did while messing with Greenshot. - I hit [prt sc] and it pops up a region selector. Now I don't have to go into GIMP or paint to crop the image, Greenshot does it for me. I can even edit it on the spot right here. - I can save that little astronaut guy from my background image... - Bam! I took a cropped screenshot in less than 30 seconds. Just select region and save. - You can also take separate window shots, something I should've done for my previous blog posts. Check it. - As you can see, how disorganized! Application interfaces everywhere. How do we take a aesthetically pleasing screenshot? - Simply right click Greenshot on the taskbar, and capture window from list. - That's a high quality screenshot taken in about 30 seconds. I would recommend Greenshot to anyone who owns a computer. Everyone needs to take screenshots. Whether it be trying to seek technical support, or debugging software projects. What are you waiting for? Download Greenshot Here.

item.title: How to set up a PHP Testing Environment in Windows 8
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded:
PHP is one of the most widely used languages today. Nearly all websites use it to dynamically create content. The old blog is written in pure PHP -- even the stylesheet is generated by PHP. Facebook is built entirely in PHP too, but compiles the code into C++ using HipHop. Here's the source for HipHop for those interested. If you look in Craigslist, you'll see that in Jobs -> Software/Web, that PHP jobs are high in demand. I guarantee you'll see more PHP positions than say, Python. (If you did, prove me wrong)! That's because most websites written in the internet bubble are in PHP. Ruby on Rails, Django, and Java are effective web development languages -- but people don't want to rewrite their entire website framework. But I digress. You get the point, PHP is an employable language widely used in the world, and you should learn it. How do you learn a server side scripting language? It's not as easy as python or java, you can't just throw it on a terminal. This tutorial will show you how to set up a Localhost on Windows 8 to test PHP.  

Step 1 : Turn on Windows IIS (Internet Information Systems)

- Go to Control Panel - Go to Programs - Go to Turn Windows features on or off, and check Internet Information Systems. - Let it download and do it's thing. - Check the CGI checkbox as shown here. - Let it download and do it's thing. - Now we got IIS ready to go. - Find the Internet Informations application on the Metro UI to check and quirk it's configurations.  

Step 2: Downloading PHP

- Now that localhost exists, lets get PHP. - Go to your address bar and write this 
localhost/
- If you see the pretty IIS page, you're on track. - But we don't have PHP yet! - Download PHP for Windows 8 here. - Make sure to download PHP in root. - Now let's test our first PHP page.

Step 3: First PHP Script

- Go to the following directory: 
C:\inetpub\wwwroot
- You'll have to put reading and writing privileges here in order to make files here. - Don't know how to set file permissions? Look it up, it's very simple. - Now open your favorite Text Editor. - Write the following text there: 
<?php phpinfo(); ?>
- Save it as phpinfo.php into the web root I showed you. - Now type this into your address. 
localhost/phpinfo.php
- If you installed everything correctly, you should see this. - Congratulations! You are now set to test any PHP file/application. You can also test other web programming languages by downloading the CGI, as you did simply with PHP. Just save it in that folder (namely, the web root) and access it via localhost. - Start reading w3schools, online tutorials, and e-books to learn more because PHP is a very valuable language in this world. - Once I reach a certain amount of facebook page likes, I will publicize my guest FTP which will have many e-books for PHP as well as many other languages. - As always, comments and criticisms are appreciated.

item.title: Losslessly Compress PNGs Using Optipng
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded:
As you can see here, I compressed this 500kb PNG by 80kb. PNG's are the highest quality image format, but also the largest. (Excluding Animated GIFs). Most websites have a limit on the size of the images you can upload. Also, webpages load faster if your images are compressed. So it's a good idea to start optimizing your PNGs. Using Optipng can do this without affecting your image quality. It's a command line application -- However, it's not as difficult as it looks. Download Optipng here.  

How to use Optipng

- This is our first command line application. If you never used Linux, this is foreign matter. Here's the basics. - Open Command Prompt. (Search Command Prompt in your Windows search) - Change to the directory where Optipng.exe is located. default named (Optipng-0,7,4-win32). You change the folder name and move it for future convenience. - This is the syntax to change directory. Obviously, replace "Me" with your username and wherever your Optipng is located. 
cd C:\User\Me\Downloads\Optipng-0,7,4-win32
- Now that we're at the application location, The syntax is this to optimize the images. It should look like the images above when correctly executed. 
optipng [options] file.png
- Example: 
optipng C:\User\Me\Images\mycutedog.png
- Another example: 
optipng C:\User\Me\*.png
- This compresses all of the PNG's in the directory "Me". It's wise practice to compress your images before uploading. There's nothing worse than overloaded servers, slow websites, and the inability to upload mycutedog.png.

Video:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TLNkk8pl0P8

item.title: How to Make Animated GIFs in GIMP
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded:
This is a GIF I made in about 5 minutes. It shows Wilfred punching a hole in the wall as an image, not as a video that has to be uploaded to youtube then referred to with a link. The portability is awesome, you can post GIFs on Forums, use them as Site banners, and many more. The usability and entertainment with GIFs are only limited by your imagination. Pronounced "Jiff" and standing for "Graphics Interchange Format", it is an image that can be animated.

Step 1: Downloading GAP

- First you will need GIMP 2.8, which is the most recent release. - So now we download the GIMP add-on GAP (Gimp Animation Package). - Link to GAP download: Deviantart - You should be here. Hit the small download link in the bottom right. - Unzip contents to Desktop or somewhere - You should have extracted "lib" and "share".

Step 2: Installing GAP

- Open up your GAP files and your GIMP files. - Should look like this. - Open "lib" in your "GIMP 2" folder. It should be in Program Files. - Open "lib" from your GAP stuff - Go to "Plug-ins" for both folders. - Copy the .exe files from the GAP plug-ins to the GIMP plug-ins - Should look like this after copying. - Open "share" in your "GIMP 2" folder. - Open "share" from your GAP stuff - Go to "Scripts" for both folders - Copy the two .scm files from the GAP scripts to the GIMP scripts - Should look like this after copying. - Launch GIMP! - Congrats, if you see the "Video" Tab, you have installed GAP successfully.

Step 3: Making the GIF

- Now that you have everything set up, let's make the GIF. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3alKZi3nfHM

item.title: How to install WordPress in 5 Minutes
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded:
As you may have noticed, Chakeda.com has migrated from sphpblog to WordPress. This improved many aspects of the website such as design, speed, ease of access, and navigation. I would vouch for WordPress anytime of the day to every webmaster. Therefore, I have written a Video going through the installation process of WordPress in less than 5 minutes: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CbxJXZ-YNSI

What you will need:

  • A domain and hosting, of course.
  • Database details: You can find this in the Hosting details of your hosting provider. For GoDaddy, Login -> Web Hosting -> Launch -> Databases (if you don't have a database, make one) -> Actions -> Details. Write down your database name, username, password, and hostname. You will need this later.
  • FileZilla
[caption width="1366" align="alignnone"] You will need database details on this step. Example details above. [/caption]

Tutorial

  1. Download WordPress.
  2. Unzip contents.
  3. Upload contents of the unzipped WordPress file to the directory you want WordPress installed. You can also upload it all to the root folder.
  4. Once the upload is finished, access the directory where you uploaded WordPress. Example: If you uploaded to root, go to "chakeda.com". If you uploaded to the directory "blog" go to "chakeda.com/blog/".
  5. Create the config.php file automatically.
  6. Enter your database details.
  7. Enter your website preferences, and your desired username and password.
  8. Login.
  9. You can now edit your wordpress website!
The installation can't get easier. Wordpress is used by nearly 70% of domain websites. CNN runs on WordPress, and most of the websites you frequent use it as well. Drupal comes in second, but non-web developers usually haven't even heard of Drupal. Jump on the wagon and install WordPress -- You won't regret it.

item.title: GifCam : Create Animated GIFs From Your Screen
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded: We learned how to create an animated gif from individual images using CaptureIt Plus. And back in January, we learned how to create a gif from video. Gifs continue to be a popularly shared file format; most forums, social media, and imageboards only allow images, and videos have to be linked to. With a gif, we can share moving images which are relatively small in size. Videos are heavy and have to be linked to; but a gif is sure to catch a surfers attention or make a laugh. In this article we learn a third way to create gifs: recording directly from your screen. This is definitely the easiest way to create animated gifs: simply ready a frame and record from your screen. You don't have to go through the lengthy process of the GIMP method. GifCam is an innovative, lightweight application that can create gifs by recording a frame on your screen. GifCam can also export as a png or even avi, potentially replacing screenshot utility software such as Greenshot and screen capturing software such as hypercam. Think of Gifcam as the lightweight application that can capture images, moving images, and even video. GifCam along with the userscript YouTube Center allows you to create all kinds of GIFs from YouTube. You can download the YouTube videos, and create gifs using the GIMP method. If you just want to make a gif from one part of the video, simply use Gifcam and you don't have to download the video. Keep in mind that GIFs are very large: GifCam itself cannot customize framerate unlike the GAP + GIMP GIF creating method. Gifcam has limited customizability compared to the GIMP method, but you can select from three framerates: 10, 16, and 32 fps. The size can be potentially massive if you use 32fps; a 5 second video can exceed 8 megabytes if the dimensions are large enough. User-friendly Gif making is this tool's most appealing feature. You can make the GIF grayscale, toggle cursor capturing, and capture full screen all through a UI. Here's a quick tutorial on how to download and use Gifcam. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lhTKpzS6Dqo Welcome to the world of making gifs! Download GifCam from their official website.

item.title: How to Blur Parts of a Video using Camtasia Studio 8
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded: When you make a video, sometimes things that you don't want to be seen are included. Whether it be your face, sensitive information, or something inappropriate, you'll have to obfuscate it before sending it to YouTube. You definitely don't want the 4th highest Alexa ranked website to see your e-mail on your screencast, or your face on a controversial video. In order to censor parts of a video, the trialware Camtasia Studio greatly facilitates the process. Blurring an arbitrary part of a video takes no more than a minute. Here's the tutorial video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4cCwddlqyKs Warning Camtasia Studio is trialware. This is the first time Chakeda Software vouched for something that's not freeware. Additionally, the download at techsmith will prompt you to install the nasty toolbars. [caption width="1024" align="alignnone"] Toolbars are evil![/caption] Camtasia is available for download at Cnet and Softonic. Both are notorious for installing adware with their featured software. However, uninstalling toolbars are not so difficult. The techsmith download that I used installed the Download Manager Adware. However, this can be simply uninstalled from your Control Panel -> Programs -> Uninstall Programs. This is the small price we have to pay for the powerful software. Not to mention you can always reuse trialware by uninstalling the software before the trial period is over -- then reinstalling it. So as the video says, trialware is pretty much freeware. Not to mention cracks are available throughout the Internet.

item.title: How to Migrate from sphpblog to WordPress
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1366"] From this...[/caption] [caption width="1366" align="alignnone"] ...to this. [/caption] To most, migrating a website is a huge hassle. Even a blogger to WordPress can be a hassle, even though there is a script for it. It's the same reason why we don't move all the time in real life: because we're comfortable at home and switching houses is undoubtfully a hassle. However, it is a necessary process in a website's lifetime. Maybe your blogspot domain's SEO capability isn't drawing enough visitors. Maybe your CMS is not allowing you enough customization. Maybe your website needs a complete renovation? Chakeda.com has been powered by the open source CMS sphpblog for half an year. I decided to use this simple program so I can learn how a CMS works and gain useful PHP experience. However, sphpblog has not been touched by developers since 2007. That year marks the point when WordPress became paramount over all CMS, including sphpblog. I came to realize sphpblog's many flaws over the months. Here's what comes to mind:
  • Severely outdated. Programming untouched since 2007.
  • Aesthetically outdated, no web 2.0 support such as Social Media integration.
  • Does not support HTML5/CSS3 and other upcoming web programming languages.
  • Blog links kept in querystrings; terrible for SEO.
  • Content kept in text files, compromising security and affecting performance.
  • Open source. This has its advantages, but security is compromised.
  • MarkItUp, a javascript text editor, is used for adding entries. This too is severely outdated, last modified in 2011.
  • No video embed support. Can't promote Chakeda Software on Youtube.
  • Severely outdated.
However, I learned many things by constantly tweaking with sphpblog. I initially launched chakeda.com for web programming experience -- now I am focused on webmaster experience. WordPress experience is as desirable in the work force as PHP experience, considering WordPress powers 1 in 6 of every website in the world. WordPress still gives opportunities to learn web programming: the functions and stylesheets are available to edit. Granted, it's not as customizable as full access to the CMS source code, but experience is being gained. In any case, increasing web standards and many other reasons prompts webmasters to make migrations. Here's the video to migrate from sphpblog to WordPress. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-MFy0OFvud4

item.title: How to fill out a PDF W9 Form Electronically
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded: Sometime someday, you will stop publishing software tutorials to the Internet and start to look for a job. Or maybe you won't. In any case, it is good practice to learn how to edit PDFs manually. Proprietary software such as PDFCreator and PDFArchitect doesn't allow many features unless you pay the subscription fee, which can be upwards to $50 a month. We are trying to get a job by filling out PDF applications, not losing money. Additionally, web applications that claim to convert a PDF to an editable DOC format are highly unreliable. Again, it is likely proprietary, and the process usually messes up the format from my experience. If you had a good experience using an online converter, please enlighten us. Meanwhile, my money is on GIMP for editing PDFs. Loosely explained, A W9 Form is required for reporting an income tax for a job. Most large corporations can do this process for you, but sometimes you will have to fill it out yourself. There are two ways you can do this; send a copy to them via postal service, or send them one electronically. Like always, we want to save money because we're looking for a job. Instead of paying for stamps, lets fill out the PDF W9 form electronically using GIMP. This video will teach you how to use GIMP to edit a PDF successfully for official documents: a W9 Tax Form for example. You will need no previous experience in GIMP. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lz2Rj5A07Os I forgot to add: If the PDF doesn't come out how you like it after flattening and exporting, you will have to hit ctrl-z to unflatten the image; then you can edit the PDF again.

item.title: How to Create a 302 Redirect with .htaccess
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded: [caption width="1366" align="alignnone"] Sample .htaccess configuration file. Simple, isn't it?[/caption] An .htaccess file (hypertext access) is server side configuration file, which can override the global web server configurations of the directory where it is placed. In layman's terms, it's a special file that can do stuff on your website. It can be used to password protect directories, block google spiders, and even create customized 404 pages. However, the most notable usage is to create website redirections. A .htaccess redirection can be used for many things. A website migration, dealing with broken links or old links, and link cloaking. In this article, we will focus on two from of redirection: 301 and 302. The 301 redirect is search engine friendly, so this should be employed for seamless website migrations and bad links. The 302 redirect means temporarily moved; so this should be used for link cloaking or temporary fixes on your website. This video will show you how to create a .htaccess file with a text editor, then uploading it via ftp. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sTD8opXig2c So, the website redirection syntax is as follows: Redirect [302] [website or directory to direct from] [destination link] Here's an example seen in the picture above: Redirect 302 /blog/ http://www.chakeda.com When this .htaccess file is in the directory "blog", every visitor who visits the directory or its derivative files will be automatically directed to www.chakeda.com. However, a 301 redirect will be better for this example, as the 302 redirect will prevent search engine crawlers. Let's see some more htaccess redirection examples: Redirect 301 http://www.chakeda.com/blog/index.php?entry=entry131111-121358 http://chakeda.com/7zip-strongest-compression-type/ This is a search engine friendly article redirection method. When people visit that entry on my old blog, they are redirected to the entry on the new blog. Your SERP will not be affected: however, the description text will be the same as the old blog's entry. Last example: Link cloak Redirect 302 /offers/applebees.html http://www.applebees.com/redeemgiftcard/ A 302 should be employed for CPA Link cloaking, as Google doesn't like CPA. As you can see now, creating an .htaccess file is easy. However, make sure you know when to use a 302 and a 301.

item.title: Everybody Should Have a Website in 2014
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_220" align="alignnone" width="630"] iPage can help you get your website started, fast.[/caption] The year is 2014. For everybody, the Internet is a part of their being. We wake up, we go on the Internet to check social media and our favorite websites. We get to work, and we spend most of the time on the Internet, productively or unproductively. If you don't know something, you Google it; and virtually any problem in the world can be answered. We come home to the Internet for respite. We laugh and learn from the Internet, and some people make a living off the Internet. The Internet is our life in 2014. We become a part of it and utilize the Internet's full potential by creating a website of our own. There are four main reasons to create a website: increasing employability, business expansion/creation, making money, and even curing boredom. Now ask yourself this: why don't you have a website? When an employer finds a potential employee, they go on the Internet and Google their name. A personal website can increase your job finding prospects, as you have the capability to create a website, and you possess the confidence to display your employability globally. A traditional resume is customary, but having a website puts you on top of the pile. When the employer visits your website, you can amaze him with all of your past work. This is especially powerful for designers, artists, writers, programmers, photographers, and basically any job that you could want. Website resumes, unlike printed resumes, supports media such as videos and images; something that can wow your employers. Having a website will get you employed. [caption id="attachment_305" align="alignnone" width="571"] iPage has abundant functionality (and free advertising credits) for beginners and experts.[/caption] Billions upon billions of people access the Internet everyday. Consider this; where is a better place to launch your business? Nowadays when people look for a service, product, business, or store, the first thing they do is Google it. Even when a thought crosses someones mind, they Google it nowadays. Creating an e-store will change your audience from local to global. That can potentially increase your earning exponentially. However, you don't need to go through the hassle of creating a business to make money online. There are a myriad of ways to make money online without a product. The first step to turn a profit on the entire world is creating an Internet presence. So, you're not an ambitious person. You don't have projects that are ready for employer review, and you don't have prospects about starting a business. However, creating a website can turn your life around. Chakeda Software Tutorials started as a simple forum. I was an extremely bored, unemployed man. I decided to buy a domain out of impulse. Eventually, I started catching traffic, and started creating articles. My life had a meaning again. I got busy, finding joy in people learning from my articles, and helping people in need. I got valuable programming experience, working with an open source CMS. I also used iPage's drag and drop website creator, which greatly facilitated the creation of the website, but I preferred a challenge. My resume had one powerful employment title: Webmaster. Additionally, I employed advertisements on my website, and started earning me a decent income to help pay my bills and more. Creating a website turned my life around, turning me into a productive, successful, and ambitious man. Now, ask yourself this question again. Why don't you have a website? If you didn't answer with "because I just now read this article today", let me ask you another question. What do you have to lose? Creating a website with iPage only costs $12 a year and they have an anytime money back guarantee. I know, when I heard it, I couldn't believe it too. But I bought the domain and hosting, and I was extremely satisfied with the price and service. Chakeda.com is proudly hosted on iPage. For those who have never bought a website, let me explain the process for you. A domain is the name of the website. You reserve it, and it is yours; like "chakeda.com". Hosting is the price you pay for having the website files on the hosting companies computers. For iPage, the hosting only costs $12 a year, with a free domain name. Compare that to the $60 GoDaddy charges for their "premium hosting". Here's a quick video from iPage. iPage has a anytime money back guarantee, and over $300 in value of advertising credits. You would be crazy to not at least try iPage out. What do you have to lose? Host your website with iPage!

item.title: How to Create a Puppy Linux USB Drive using VirtualBox
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded: [caption width="1366" align="alignnone"] Puppy Linux in VirtualBox. So cute and cuddly. [/caption] Linux is something Chakeda Software Tutorials hasn't touched on in a while. Mostly because Linux is pretty difficult, and it takes time to create video tutorials, because I have to debug everything. However, through popular request, Chakeda Software will start creating Linux Tutorials. One of our most popular tutorials is the Dual Booting Windows 8 and Ubuntu tutorial. Many people require guidance in the open source Linux community, and I am glad to contribute. Puppy Linux is a very small linux distribution, capable of running on RAM. This is very useful in that it can run on extremely old Computers, or with computers with broken hard drives. Effectively, if you have a Puppy Linux Live USB, you can salvage virtually any computer. The Puppy Linux USB is basically a zombie raising staff with unlimited uses. (Been playing way too much Skyrim) Now installing Puppy Linux is difficult. It is hard to run effectively as a dual boot with Windows 8, unlike Ubuntu, which supports Legacy Boot. The best way to use Puppy Linux is through a Live USB. However, Puppy Linux is not able to create a Live USB, as they don't support a USB creator. You have to install Puppy Linux to access their live USB creator. So here are out options. - Dual Boot Puppy Linux and create the bootable USB. (Takes a long time) - Burn Puppy on a CD, then burn it again on a USB (Takes a long time) - Run Puppy on VirtualBox, and create the bootable USB. Here's Chakeda Software's video tutorial on the 3rd method. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jmpwKiv78UU What you need: - Puppy Linux ISO : Ubuntu compatible (Lucid Puppy) - VirtualBox with Extension Pack Step 1 : How to run Puppy Linux on Virtualbox - You may have to enable virtualization technology in BIOS. Also, you will need to enable PAE/NX in the VM settings. Everything else is shown in the video. Step 2 : How to Create a Bootable Puppy Linux USB Stick - In the video, one of my USB drives wasn't compatible with Puppy Linux. You may have to try another USB drive if one doesn't work. Also for some reason, the formatting wizard didn't work on the first try, sorry about that. Everything else is shown in the video. Step 3 : How to boot the Puppy Linux USB on a Computer - You will have to go into BIOS and configure your boot order: USB should be first. Now, if your Puppy Linux flash drive is in when you start your computer, you will have the option to run it.

item.title: How to Create a Torrent with qBitTorrent
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded:
We all downloaded something through a torrent once in our lifetime. P2P (peer to peer) is the future of networking, where we all share our bandwidth instead of assailing one server. P2P networking has gained infamy from Piratebay and its numerous lawsuits. If you haven't torrented before, it's because of the Piratebay defamations; and the risk for copyright infringement. P2P has gained a negative reputation in a legal and moral view. However, many Linux distributions are available for download through torrents, because the download is faster. However, I won't go into depth how to safely download and upload torrents for now. I could go on and on about torrenting safety, so I will create a separate article for that. In any case, better safe than sorry. I'll summarize torrenting safely: Use qBitTorrent or another Open Source Client. This is the most important step: uTorrent is affiliated with the DMCA. Its file size increases everyday, and we have no idea what kind of backdoors it's implementing in the system because it is closed source. Also, change your IP address after torrenting. Finally, avoid copyrighted media such as Disney movies. Now that we're safe, let's make the torrent. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KDQxwlgT1ws Once you save your .torrent file, you can start sending your torrent. Whenever someone opens your .torrent file, you start uploading the torrent contents to him. The seeding speed will be the same as your upload speed, so it is advisable to upload the torrent to Piratebay to get more peers. However, Piratebay has been known to ban new members instantly and indiscriminately, so you may need to gain more seeders from other file sharing services, friends, or communities.

Text Tutorial

- Download qBitTorrent. - Ready the file/folder you want to upload. - Go to tools. - Go to torrent creator. - Browse to the file/folder you want to upload. - Enter your tracker URLS. Use these if you don't have any. udp://tracker.openbittorrent.com:80 udp://tracker.publicbt.com:80 udp://tracker.istole.it:6969 udp://tracker.ccc.de:80 udp://open.demonii.com:1337 - Select start seeding after creation. - Save the .torrent wherever you like. - You will start seeding the torrent if everything went well. - Share the .torrent file to increase seeders and leechers!

item.title: How to Spoof your MAC Address
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_272" align="alignnone" width="669"] This is your MAC Address. [/caption] What is a MAC Address? Many people think the only way your computer can be identified by is through IP addresses. The MAC (Media Access Control) address consists of 12 characters, and denotes the physical location of your computer. As you can see in the video, MAC addresses have a corresponding location with them. So even if you change your IP Address, your MAC Address remains the same, so your physical identity is exposed. In this video tutorial, we learn to change our physical identity by using a "MAC Spoof". For example, 02-18-F2-03-D5-0E is the MAC address of "Beijing Tianyu Communication Equipment Co., Ltd (Address: 27th Floor, Tengda Plaza, Xizhimengwai Street, Haidian District, Beijing 100044, CHINA)". This is found through TMAC (Technitium MAC Address Changer), which is the software we use to manipulate our MAC address in the following video. To find your MAC address, open command prompt and enter ipconfig /all or download TMAC and check it out. So when we change our MAC Address to this location, any website will detect your IP Address as is, but consider you a different physical entity. Now I won't get into detail because networking is complicated. MAC Spoofing can help circumvent IP block/bans and other things that proxies cannot do. In any case of Internet privacy, it's better to be safe than sorry. Changing your IP address is easy and can circumvent the simplest of things, but you require a Dynamic IP Address. Some people have Static IP addresses and cannot change their IP address unless they call their ISP. MAC Spoofing is the solution to this. This can circumvent simple things as well. Multi-VPN/Proxies are a better idea when you want to be extra safe, but most web applications can detect these services. If you change your IP address and MAC address, consider yourself a new person on the Internet. This video will show you how to change your MAC address using TMAC on windows 8. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=imvA2SRGla4

item.title: IP Timeout Link Creator
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_275" align="alignnone" width="1366"] IP Timeout Link Creator[/caption] Chakeda presents the IP Timeout Link Creator (IPTLC). Simply enter an URL, and the output is a link that will deny the IP of the visitor for an arbitrary amount of time after redirecting to your URL. This is useful for redirections which requires the user to be unique, or if you need someone to have a different IP for testing purposes. The application also blocks proxies by detecting header elements. This is useful in that the user will be checked to see if genuine. Here is the PHP code for the proxy blocker: $proxy_headers = array( 'HTTP_VIA', 'HTTP_X_FORWARDED_FOR', 'HTTP_FORWARDED_FOR', 'HTTP_X_FORWARDED', 'HTTP_FORWARDED', 'HTTP_CLIENT_IP', 'HTTP_FORWARDED_FOR_IP', 'VIA', 'X_FORWARDED_FOR', 'FORWARDED_FOR', 'X_FORWARDED', 'FORWARDED', 'CLIENT_IP', 'FORWARDED_FOR_IP', 'HTTP_PROXY_CONNECTION' ); foreach($proxy_headers as $x){ if (isset($_SERVER[$x])) die("You are using a proxy!"); } This PHP code snippet will block most SOCKS proxies, but not browser based proxies such as hidemyass and VPNs. Most proxy services spoof http headers to go through proxy detections like this. However, websites like Worldofwarcraft.com use a stylesheet trick to block proxies; however, the best it can do is block CSS from loading. Unfortunately, PHP cannot completely defend against proxies. Another way you can filter identities is through checking MAC addresses. However, Internet Explorer is the only browser that exposes the user's MAC address. Many services consider a different MAC address and same IP as the same user as the same IP. Therefore, if you have a static IP address, the best bet to changing your online identity is through getting a new ISP, and get a Dynamic subnet. Century Link almost always supports Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol, so you may want to consider switching from Warner Cable or some obsolete ISP like that. In any case, IPTLC will ensure that any visitor going through your link is unique and genuine, by checking for a unique IP. It also filters proxies so the user is not a easily identifiable fake visitor. Please let me know if there are any bugs.

item.title: How to Extract EXIF Data from Images
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded: [caption width="1366" align="alignnone"] EXIF Data from Exifer.[/caption] Did you know most all images have hidden metadata within them? When you take a photo with a camera or smartphone, the device records all the information it can in the image. This includes the date taken, hardware information, resolution information, and even the GPS coordinates of the image. This metadata is known as EXIF (Exchangeable image file format) data. Exifer is an application that can show you the EXIF data of an image. With this, you can get significant data from the image: who took it, what device took it, when it was taken, and even where it was taken. It also notes if it went through image manipulation. Photo resolution information is also found, so stronger investigation can be done on whether the image has been manipulated or not. You can also find the exact GPS location of where the image was taken. The most important piece of EXIF data is the GPS coordinates of the image taken. This can potentially be used for revealing very sensitive information. However, most social media strips EXIF data from images. So you cannot find the GPS coordinates of your celebrity crush. Some websites also do this to protect their users. This hindrance reduces the power of EXIF data. However, it is always worth a shot. Obviously Facebook and Twitter rip EXIF data, but amateur sites usually retain EXIF. Most image manipulation applications retain EXIF data, notably Photoshop. Old applications are known to destroy EXIF data upon manipulation, notably old versions of MS paint. In any case, if some dumb person sends you a picture of his ding dong, you can investigate the EXIF data and turn him to the authorities, or send him a nice hot pizza. There are numerous other uses for this. EXIF data can be used for good, or for the bad. The NSA does it, why shouldn't you? Here's a video on how to download and use EXIF data, with a quick explanation of what I just went through above. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lA6o9Uy0f6c

item.title: How to Start Making Money Online
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_323" align="alignnone" width="900"] This could be you![/caption] When people hear the concept of making money online, they feel skeptical. Many think of it as a myth. However, with the right information and resource, the real potential of the Internet is revealed -- and the potential to the "Internet billionaire" begins. I personally know people who make thousands upon thousands of dollars a month. They possess a surplus of the right information and resource. However, the reason why making money online is a myth is because of not knowing where to start. How someone makes money online is almost inconceivable to the Internet naive person. Most people have heard of AdSense. Most of the Internet naive surely go on YouTube, and see those annoying advertisements. And most people understand that the video uploaders gain revenue from people watching those advertisements. A click on the advertisement yields the uploader more money than the simple view. This is a very simple method of making money online. AdSense grants even the Internet naive to make a large amount of money, with or without a website. Another use of AdSense is on a website. Anyone has seen an AdSense banner advertisement. It works similar to the YouTube AdSense synthesis above. When a visitor clicks on the advertisement, the website owner gains revenue. This method of making money online is widely know as PPC (Pay Per Click). AdSense is a very simple way of making money online. You simply generate content as a video, website, or even mobile application. Slap the ads on it, and the next step is to gain as much visitors to your content as possible. The clicks have to be made through genuine interest per AdSense terms of service, and the average percentage of people genuinely clicking on an AdSense advertisement is about 2%. The CPC (Cost per Click) can range from a couple cents to $20. This number is dependent on your niche, which is the specific market you target your content on. An example of a low CPC niche is Pets, and a high CPC niche is auto insurance. I may explained the basic concept of making money online too fast for some, or too slow for some. In summary, I introduce the simplest way of making money online: AdSense. However, there are many other methods of making money online. For example, CPA (Cost/Commission per Acquisition/Action), PPD (Pay per Download), and PPP (Pay per Project). Chakeda Software will start writing tutorials on Making Money Online. We will present basic information , stories of success and failure, and methods that teach you step by step how to make money online. We will still write articles on Free Software Tutorials.

item.title: cFeed : Invisible Open Source Live Website Traffic Feed
item.dc:creator: chakeda
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_333" align="alignnone" width="1366"] cFeed in action for chakeda.com. Check it out here.[/caption] Chakeda.com presents cFeed, the first open source alternative to web traffic tracking. It allows anyone to track their website visitors for free, invisibly, and lighweightly. It combines the simplicity of Feedjit and the functionality of Statcounter into one web application. I started programming cFeed to create an Open Source alternative to web traffic monitoring. I noticed there is no open source alternative to web traffic monitoring. There are three prominent web applications for monitoring website traffic: Feedjit, Statcounter, and Google Analytics. All three are closed source; we don't know what they're doing with our website data. I have used all three, and noticed all have their flaws. cFeed aims to find a functional middle ground for the three: Feedjit's simplicity, Statcounter's functionality, and Google Analytic's power. As depicted in the picture above, cFeed is visibly similar to Feedjit. However, it is connected to freegeoip, so more data can be returned (like Statcounter) so long as the front-end is developed. [caption id="attachment_334" align="alignnone" width="1366"] As you can see, cFeed is visibly similar to Feedjit.[/caption] cFeed is a web application written in PHP, and is hosted on chakeda.com. The user enters his/her website url, and picks his/her platform (WordPress, Blogger, or universal code). A piece of external JavaScript is then given to the user, which they will then put in their header or sidebar. The JavaScript sends visitor data via cross domain AJAX to the chakeda.com database. The visitor data is depicted on a cfeed page made for the website. Sounds like Feedjit, doesn't it? However, cFeed is not meant to be an imitation of Feedjit: but an open source live website traffic feed. This allows webmasters to safely track their data, being fully aware of where it goes. Also, it is freely customizable to the webmaster. cFeed is currently working at its bare bones, at about 1000 lines of code. Functionality is minimal. However, I plan on making much more functionality. Here's a list of ideas. This list will be frequently updated on cFeed's Github Readme.
  • Coloring of IPs for individual visitor tracking
  • Daily/Weekly/Monthly amount of website impressions count
  • Ability to host cFeed on the user's website, so they can see the feed on their own website instead of chakeda.com
  • Visitor's time spent on the website
  • Further traffic analysis, like Statcounter's graphs
If you want to start tracking your website traffic using open source software, contribute to cFeed, or just stay updated to cFeed's advancements, here are the links.
  • cFeed on GitHub (Contribute or check out the code)
  • cFeed in action (Chakeda.com's website traffic used as example)
  • Open Source Live Website Traffic Feed (Start using cFeed!)
